item.title: MindsEye Exec Says He's "Caught" the Game's So-Called Saboteurs
item.content:encoded:
Mark Gerhard, CEO of MindsEye developer Build a Rocket Boy, says the studio has "caught" the so-called saboteurs responsible for a smear campaign against the game, and the next step is legal action, apparently.

According to a new Insider Gaming report, Gerhard told BARB staffers that the studio's management has "caught the guys who've been sabotaging MindsEye", and that the company behind the sabotage is a "very big American company".

Gerhard goes on to say that the alleged smear campaign apparently had the weight of more than €1 million behind it, and that it was orchestrated by a UK-based creator platform called Ritual Network, which Gerhard describes as "a bunch of gangsters".

Several individuals, including influencer Cyberboi, a number of journalists, and some Build a Rocket Boy employees, will apparently be "served in person, criminal complaints, shortly", with those complaints alleging "espionage, sabotage, and criminal interference".

Insider Gaming contacted Ritual Network for comment, and the platform told the publication that it is "not involved in the matter". It goes on to say that it's "not aware of any legitimate legal action" brought by Build a Rocket Boy, and that any suggestion it's connected to the aforementioned sabotage is "incorrect".

Build a Rocket Boy, however, insists that it's on the right track; in a statement, it told Insider Gaming that it has "evidence that there has been a co-ordinated campaign to purposefully and maliciously damage" both the studio and the game, and that it's "taking steps" to address the issue.

In case you need a reminder, MindsEye launched last year to a pretty negative reception across the board, seemingly leading to layoffs at Build a Rocket Boy shortly after the game's launch, as well as publisher IO Interactive seemingly pulling back from third-party publishing.

Build a Rocket Boy recently announced it will split from IO Interactive and publish the game itself going forward, although given that former employees have alleged that many of MindsEye's problems stem from BARB and not from IO, it's not clear to what degree that will change things.

MindsEye is available now for PC, PlayStation 5, and Xbox Series X|S, should you wish to try it. You can read our review here to find out why you probably shouldn't.

item.title: Baldur's Gate TV Show In the Works from The Last of Us Co-Creator
item.content:encoded:
Celebrated CRPG franchise Baldur's Gate is getting its very own TV show, according to a new report, and it'll be brought to you by none other than The Last of Us co-creator and showrunner Craig Mazin.

Per a new Deadline report, the show is being developed for HBO and seems to be based on the series as a whole, although it will apparently take place directly after the events of Baldur's Gate 3 and will deal with the ramifications of those events.

Mazin won't just be the showrunner, either; he's also attached as a writer and executive producer, alongside folks from Wizards of the Coast and its owner Hasbro, as you'd expect from a TV show based on a Dungeons & Dragons property.

According to Mazin, he's a big fan of Larian's latest entry into the iconic CRPG series; he says he's put "nearly 1000 hours" into the game, and that he's a "devoted fan" not only of Baldur's Gate but of Dungeons & Dragons in general.

Although the show will be based on Baldur's Gate, Deadline says it won't draw from the first two games in the series too much, since they're not "official source material", according to the publication.

With that said, there will be "some commonalities across those games" that also refer to general Dungeons & Dragons lore, and those might come into Mazin's new Baldur's Gate show.

It's worth noting that this is a distinct entity from the upcoming Forgotten Realms TV show, which is being made for Netflix. It's unlikely, therefore, that the two will cross over in any meaningful way, at least not to begin with.

Baldur's Gate is just one of the video game franchises getting itself a TV adaptation. It joins the likes of Ubisoft's Far Cry, Sony's God of War, and Bethesda and MachineGames' Wolfenstein, among many others.

We're still likely a long way away from the Baldur's Gate TV show being released, but stay tuned for more info about this as and when we get it.
